page.title: 16CRANHAM WOODS
page.content: Cranham Woods are a feature of the parish and cover several square miles.Most are owned by Major Birchall or Witcombe Estates. The trees are mostly beechwith some yew and holly as undergrowth. There are many paths and bridleways, some waymarked, running through, which are well used. Betwwen the 1920's and 1948 one large house, now demolished, was a private sanatorium, and its site is now occupied by a sawmill using mainly local wood for fencing products. Squirrels, foxes, badgers and rabbits are common while roe are present but rarely seen. Kestrels and occasionally buzzards are seen and in the winter flocks of woodpigeon are very evident.In recent years considerable felling has taken place making parts of the woods very open and undergrowth is increasing.
